intro: Dianthus pratensis, commonly known as the sweet William, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the carnation family (Caryophyllaceae) and is characterized by its showy, clustered flowers that range in color from white to deep red. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces numerous pink or white flowers with prominent white veins. Its leaves are linear and grass-like, and it thrives in well-drained soil in full sun. Dianthus pratensis is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and as a cut flower.
